text: Hi, this is Julián from MinuteEarth.
Microbes are incredibly tiny.

Their name, microbe, literally means “tiny
lifeform” and to see them, you need a tiny
lifeform-seer, more commonly known as a microscope.

Except, it’s sometimes more useful to observe
microbes from space … well, at least observe
their effects.

That’s because the impacts these tiny lifeforms
have on our planet can be so huge that they’re

visible from satellites over 400 miles away,
and that broader perspective can give us more

useful information than we could ever hope
to get by just using microscopes.

For example, certain disease-causing microbes
can infect plants.

And since the plants’ chlorophyll degrades
as the plants die turning their leaves brown,

we can step waaaaay back and use satellites
to measure changes in the visible and infrared

light coming off forests and crops to tell
whether groups of plants are healthy or dying.

While we can use microscopes to observe the
microbes infecting the plant tissue, using

space-based data is significantly more efficient
because we can inspect large swaths of land
in minutes.

Forests cover a third of US land, but with
satellite data, forest managers can easily

prioritize monitoring on areas where dying
and drying trees may be most likely to go
up in flames.

And farmers can decide whether they should
continue expending resources on potentially

disease-doomed crops without having to inspect
acres of land on foot, which not only saves

them money, but also saves the environment
from wasted water and excess fertilizer.

Satellites can also pick up chlorophyll reflected
off huge blooms of another microbe, phytoplankton.

The scale of these blooms would be impossible
to document with microscopes, or even just

from the Earth's surface, since it would take
a ship 11 years to collect as much data on

phytoplankton as a single satellite does every
two minutes.

And there’s a lot we can infer from this
data when paired with what we already know

about these microbes, like the fact that floating
blooms of phytoplankton are sometimes home
to the nasty bacterium that causes cholera.

And when ocean water occasionally floods inland,
the bacteria hitch a ride into rivers and

lakes that people use for drinking, bathing,
and cooking, killing tens of thousands of
people each year.

While we can collect samples from water sources
and inspect them for the cholera-causing bacteria,

satellite data showing a combination of warm
waters, high ocean levels, and a concentration

of phytoplankton can help us forecast cholera
outbreaks before they reach these waterways,
which can help save many lives.

And satellites may soon help us find life
on other planets too!

Looking at Earth, they've been able to identify
tiny cracks in salt-rich rocks that were caused
by salt-loving microbes.

And looking at Mars, satellites are now finding
those same patterns in salt-rich Martian rocks,

which suggests the same kind of microbes once
lived on Mars!

Using that knowledge, we’ve started to direct
our microscope-equipped rovers to the most
likely locations to find traces of life.

So, satellites will never completely replace
lab work and on the ground observations; we

still need microscopes to learn more about
how those bacteria work in the first place.

But by using both microscopes and macroscopes,
we can magnify our understanding of Earth
– and other planets.

This video was sponsored by the University
of Minnesota, where students, faculty and

staff across all fields of study are working
to solve the Grand Challenges facing society.

One of these challenges is assuring clean
water and sustainable ecosystems, which is

easier to do when we can keep an eye on the
microbes causing problems in our planet’s
water and vegetation.

Professor Jeannine Cavender-Bares in the College
of Biological Sciences and her collaborators

Professors Rebecca Montgomery and Jennifer
Juzwik in the College of Food Agriculture

and Natural Sciences have developed new methods
of detecting tree diseases using remote sensing
technology.

These tools have the potential to contribute
to sustaining forest health nationally and
globally.
Thanks, University of Minnesota!
